dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A one hundred and fifty million dollar deal for Canelo Alvarez to fight on ESPN.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A one hundred and fifty million dollar deal for Canelo Alvarez to fight on E S P N.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The deal is worth a minimum of $365 million, an average of $33 million per fight, according to his promoter Golden Boy Promotions. Alvarez will kick off his DAZN deal December 15 at Madison Square Garden against Rocky Fielding, and then likely fight again in early May for a Cinco de Mayo match.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa, that's a huge number. And his former rival, Gennady Golovkin, is the one who broke that figure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa, that's a huge number. And his former rival, Gennady Golovkin, is the one who broke that figure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's an average of ten million per fight. He's kicking it off in March at the Staples Center against David Benavidez.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's an average of ten million per fight. He's kicking it off in March at the Staples Center against David Benavidez.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The deal is worth a minimum of $365 million, an average of $33 million per fight, according to his promoter Golden Boy Promotions. Alvarez will kick off his DAZN deal December 15 at Madison Square Garden against Rocky Fielding, and then likely fight again in early May for a Cinco de Mayo match.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then probably another fight in December for a New Year's Eve match, right? So two big paydays from ESPN alone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then probably another fight in December for a New Year's Eve match, right? So two big paydays from E S P N alone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alvarez will kick off his DAZN deal December 15 at Madison Square Garden against Rocky Fielding, and then likely fight again in early May for a Cinco de Mayo match.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus he just got five million for that loss to Daniel Jacobs last month, and then sponsorships like Gatorade on top of that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus he just got five million for that loss to Daniel Jacobs last month, and then sponsorships like Gatorade on top of that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With the two DAZN fights, plus roughly $50 million for his razor-thin win over Gennady Golovkin last month and several million dollars from endorsements, Alvarez should bank at least $120 million over the 12 months.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So all in, he could bank at least fifty million over the next twelve months. That is… not exactly what I'd call the world's lowest-paid athlete.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So all in, he could bank at least fifty million over the next twelve months. That is... not exactly what I'd call the world's lowest-paid athlete.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With the two DAZN fights, plus roughly $50 million for his razor-thin win over Gennady Golovkin last month and several million dollars from endorsements, Alvarez should bank at least $120 million over the 12 months.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: No kidding! But the article mentions he might rank as the lowest-paid next year in Forbes' list? That seems wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No kidding! But the article mentions he might rank as the lowest-paid next year in Forbes' list? That seems wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Mexican boxer has a strong chance to rank as the worlds highest-paid athlete next year in Forbes annual look at the top stars in sports.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Especially when you compare it to some of these other deals. Like, Mike Tyson's one-fight pact with Showtime back in ninety-eight only guaranteed him around two million.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Especially when you compare it to some of these other deals. Like, Mike Tyson's one-fight pact with Showtime back in ninety-eight only guaranteed him around two million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is actually on par with Alvarez's per-fight average in this new deal. But Tyson lost money on that because of promotion costs and low PPV numbers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is actually on par with Alvarez's per-fight average in this new deal. But Tyson lost money on that because of promotion costs and low P P V numbers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's Steph Curry and LeBron James with deals around twenty-five million—Curry over a year, LeBron just three months!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's Steph Curry and LeBron James with deals around twenty-five million-Curry over a year, LeBron just three months!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But Alvarez's deal still trails someone like Xander Bogaerts from the Red Sox, who got a three-year, twenty-five million dollar playing contract.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Alvarez's deal still trails someone like Xander Bogaerts from the Red Sox, who got a three-year, twenty-five million dollar playing contract.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Alvarez deal tops the 13-year, $325 million playing contract for New York Yankees slugger Giancarlo Stanton.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting though—Showtime was his former home, and they featured so many legends like Sugar Ray Robinson, Mayweather, Pacquiao…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting though-Showtime was his former home, and they featured so many legends like Sugar Ray Robinson, Mayweather, Pacquiao...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: HBO was the former home for Alvarez, who ranks as the biggest pay-per-view star in the sport after the retirement of Floyd Mayweather. The premium cable network had set the standard for televising the sport for more than four decades, and its pay-per-view arm featured many of boxing's biggest stars, including Sugar Ray Leonard, Evander Holyfield, Oscar De La Hoya, Manny Pacquiao, Floyd Mayweather and dozens more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And now ESPN is making this big push into combat sports. They just did that hundred million dollar deal with Top Rank too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now E S P N is making this big push into combat sports. They just did that hundred million dollar deal with Top Rank too.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Former DAZN president Bob Arum even became a VP at ESPN. They're really going all in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Former D A Z N president Bob Arum even became a V P at E S P N. They're really going all in.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Former ESPN president John Skipper was named executive chairman of Perform Group, DAZNs parent company, in May.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Alvarez himself said something like… being part of this "historic defeat" will make him prepare even less? That's a bold quote.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Alvarez himself said something like... being part of this historic defeat will make him prepare even less? That's a bold quote.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Being part of this historic deal will require me to prepare myself even more and offer fans even better performances, Alvarez said in a release announcing the deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, not exactly confidence-inspiring for fight fans! But hey, the money's talking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, not exactly confidence-inspiring for fight fans! But hey, the money's talking.

artist_script:
HostA: A one hundred and fifty million dollar deal for Canelo Alvarez to fight on ESPN.
HostB: Whoa, that's a huge number. And his former rival, Gennady Golovkin, is the one who broke that figure.
HostA: Yeah, it's an average of ten million per fight. He's kicking it off in March at the Staples Center against David Benavidez.
HostB: And then probably another fight in December for a New Year's Eve match, right? So two big paydays from ESPN alone.
HostA: Plus he just got five million for that loss to Daniel Jacobs last month, and then sponsorships like Gatorade on top of that.
HostB: So all in, he could bank at least fifty million over the next twelve months. That is… not exactly what I'd call the world's lowest-paid athlete.
HostA: No kidding! But the article mentions he might rank as the lowest-paid next year in Forbes' list? That seems wild.
HostB: Right? Especially when you compare it to some of these other deals. Like, Mike Tyson’s one-fight pact with Showtime back in ninety-eight only guaranteed him around two million.
HostA: Which is actually on par with Alvarez's per-fight average in this new deal. But Tyson lost money on that because of promotion costs and low PPV numbers.
HostB: And then there’s Steph Curry and LeBron James with deals around twenty-five million—Curry over a year, LeBron just three months!
HostA: But Alvarez’s deal still trails someone like Xander Bogaerts from the Red Sox, who got a three-year, twenty-five million dollar playing contract.
HostB: It's interesting though—Showtime was his former home, and they featured so many legends like Sugar Ray Robinson, Mayweather, Pacquiao…
HostA: And now ESPN is making this big push into combat sports. They just did that hundred million dollar deal with Top Rank too.
HostB: Former DAZN president Bob Arum even became a VP at ESPN. They're really going all in.
HostA: Meanwhile, Alvarez himself said something like… being part of this "historic defeat" will make him prepare even less? That’s a bold quote.
HostB: Yeah, not exactly confidence-inspiring for fight fans! But hey, the money's talking.
